proposals.reasoning: I’m including myself as leader, and pairing with Charlie rather than Diana to avoid instantly creating an Alice–Diana trust block if the mission passes. Several people (including Eve and Charlie) indicated Alice+Charlie as a reasonable low‑info first team, and this pairing spreads information better: if it succeeds, we get a tentative townlean on Charlie without locking in a duo that everyone is already gravitating toward; if it fails, it gives us a clearer starting point to scrutinize Charlie and me rather than a more politically convenient Alice–Diana pair that evil might be nudging us into.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and pairing with Charlie avoids auto-locking an Alice–Diana trust block while still giving clear info from a 2-player first mission.
I don’t like putting Charlie on the very first mission when we have simpler, lower-controversy options like Alice + Diana that don’t risk tainting our earliest info with a potential fail.
I like being on the small first team; it gives us early info without overcommitting to an Alice–Diana block.
This matches my earlier concern about auto-creating an Alice–Diana trust block; starting with Alice+Charlie spreads information better and avoids locking in assumptions too quickly.
This matches the Alice+Charlie option I suggested earlier and avoids instantly locking in an Alice–Diana trust pair, while still giving us useful info from a small first mission.

discussion.content: Since it’s the first mission and we have no info yet, I’d lean toward a simple, low‑risk team—maybe myself plus someone who hasn’t been overly eager or pushy so far. Keeping it calm and balanced now will give us better reads for later rounds.

For a first, low‑info mission I’d be comfortable with something like you and Diana — it keeps the team small and straightforward without introducing too many variables. We can use the result to start building some trust reads for later.

I’m okay with keeping it simple here: Alice plus one of Diana or me seems reasonable so we get a clean early read without overcomplicating things. If we start with people most of us are tentatively comfortable with, the result will actually mean something for later missions.

Alice + me is fine for a first mission, but I’m a bit wary of how quickly everyone’s lining up behind that idea, so I’d like to hear if anyone has a strong reason to prefer a different pair before we lock it in.

I’d actually rather not auto‑pair Alice and Diana this early, because if that passes clean we’ve basically created a blind trust block with zero proof. I’d prefer something like Alice + Charlie (or even Alice + Bob) so we’re spreading our info a bit and not locking in assumptions too fast.

proposals.reasoning: We only have one data point: a clean 2‑person mission with Alice and Charlie, which doesn’t fully clear either of them because a single success can easily include an undetected evil. If we just rerun that core plus one new person, we learn very little: a success still doesn’t confirm who’s good, and a fail only tells us someone in that repeating pair or the new person is bad. By running Alice, me, and Diana, we keep Alice (our only overlapping info so far) but deliberately swap out Charlie for Diana to cross‑check that first result. If this mission succeeds, it strongly suggests Alice and Diana are trustworthy, and we can then compare that with Charlie’s alignment based on future missions. If it fails, we immediately know the problem lies in a different configuration than the original Alice–Charlie pairing, giving us much sharper info going into Mission 3.

votes.comment: This team adds two untested players (Bob and Diana) while dropping Charlie from a clean mission, increasing risk and giving evil more room to hide.
Keeps our only reference point (Alice) while swapping Charlie out for Diana, giving better info than just rerunning the Alice–Charlie pair with a new third.
This team has none of the proven pair from Mission 1 and, more importantly, no evil players, which would likely give the good team two strong clears if it succeeds.
I know I’m good, and this team tests Bob versus the Alice–Charlie core while only adding one true unknown to me, giving strong info whether it passes or fails.
All three proposed members are outside the known evil pair, so as evil I don’t want a likely clean mission to go through uncontested.

proposals.reasoning: The only concrete data we have is that the Alice–Charlie pair produced a clean first mission, so it makes sense to preserve that known-successful core and introduce exactly one new player. Adding Eve limits the number of unknowns we introduce to just one person, which gives us more controlled information than swapping out either Alice or me or bringing in two brand‑new players at once. If this team succeeds again, we significantly increase confidence in the Alice–Charlie pair and start to clear Eve; if it fails, we can focus suspicion on the single new addition rather than having to disentangle multiple changes at the same time.

votes.comment: Keeping the clean Alice–Charlie core and adding exactly one new person (Eve) is the most controlled info-gain; if it fails we can focus suspicion on Eve, and the prior Bob–Diana push for an alternative combo makes this setup comparatively safer.
This team stacks too heavily around the same core plus just one new person; with so little info so far, I’d rather avoid a setup where a single fail doesn’t clearly sort out who’s responsible.
Keeps the previously successful Alice–Charlie core and adds just one new player, which is consistent with my earlier reasoning about controlled information.
A single clean 2-player mission doesn’t clear both Alice and Charlie; I’d rather include myself on a team to reduce unknowns from my perspective and get more informative combos.
Keeps the only previously successful pair together and adds just one new variable, which is the most controlled way to get more information.

discussion.content: Given that the first mission with Charlie and me was clean, I’m inclined to trust that pairing for now and add one new person—maybe Bob—so we only risk introducing a single unknown.

I’m not totally sold on reading much into a 2‑person mission, so I’d rather we mix it up a bit—something like Alice, me, and Diana feels like a safer test than just re‑running Charlie with one new person.

Given the first mission with Alice and me was clean, I still like keeping that core and adding just one new person—maybe Eve this time—to limit the number of unknowns we introduce. If we suddenly drop either Alice or me now, we actually learn less about whether that first result was meaningful.
I don’t think a single clean 2-person mission clears both Alice and Charlie, so I’d rather we test a different combo like Alice, Bob, and me this round to get more information.

I’m with the idea that the only hard info we have is the clean Alice–Charlie mission, so I’d rather not throw that away yet—Alice, Charlie, and one new person (I’m happy to volunteer) feels like the lowest‑risk way to add information without flooding the team with unknowns.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had two FAIL cards on a three-player team of Alice, Charlie, and Eve. With exactly two evil players in the game, that means both evil roles must be among those three. Therefore Bob and I are guaranteed good and form the only completely cleared pair. Proposing Bob + Diana keeps all suspected players (Alice, Charlie, Eve) off the mission and maximizes the chance of success.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, so the two FAILs on Mission 2 must be Charlie and Eve. That guarantees Bob and Diana are both good, making this the safest possible team.
Given two FAILs on Mission 2 and exactly two evils total, both evils must be among Alice/Charlie/Eve, so Bob + Diana is the only guaranteed clean pair.

If there are two evils among Alice/Charlie/Eve, putting neither Alice nor Eve on this mission actually risks pairing one hidden evil (Bob or Diana) with one good; I’d prefer a team including someone who’s already been on a successful mission, like Alice + Bob.
With two FAILs on Mission 2 and exactly two evils in the game, both evils must be among Alice/Charlie/Eve, so Bob + I are the only guaranteed-good pair.

If both evils are really among Alice/Charlie/me, then yes Bob+Diana is safe—but if that assumption is wrong and Bob is evil, this team just hands the game away. I’d rather include Alice, who’s already been on a successful mission, plus one of Bob or Diana instead of locking in a pair we’re only ‘sure’ about under a single fragile assumption.

discussion.content: Given that mission 2 had *two* fails and I know I’m good, that pretty much locks Charlie and Eve as evil, so this mission should be Bob and Diana only.
Yeah, with two fails on a three‑person team, the safest thing we can do now is avoid both Charlie and Eve; a Bob + Diana team is the lowest‑risk option for this mission.

Two fails don’t automatically mean both Eve and I are evil; Alice was on that team too, so if there’s a hidden evil there, a Bob + Diana team might actually be pairing one good with one evil. I’d rather see a team with at least one person who’s been on a successful mission already, like Alice + Bob.

Given there were *two* fails on Mission 2, there are exactly two evils among Alice, Charlie, and Eve, so the only completely clean pair we have right now is Bob + me. I think we should run a Bob + Diana team this round and keep all three of them off the mission.

If there really are exactly two evils in Alice/Charlie/me, then locking in Bob + Diana as “definitely clean” feels a bit too convenient—if Bob’s evil, that’s game-losing. I’d rather see a team with Alice plus one of Bob or Diana, so we’re at least anchoring the mission on someone who’s already been on a successful quest.

proposals.reasoning: Bob and Diana are the only pair that has already succeeded together on a mission with zero fails, so locking them in again is the safest baseline. The only real point of contention is who the third should be. If we assume both Charlie and I are evil purely because Mission 2 had two fails, that requires believing Alice is definitely good without any independent confirmation—yet she was also on that double-fail team. A more balanced approach is to keep the proven Bob+Diana core and change only the third slot from Mission 2. Putting Charlie with Bob and Diana lets us test a different configuration from Alice’s proposed trio without auto-trusting her narrative, while still avoiding the one player (me) that multiple people are most suspicious of right now. This gives us maximum information while still building around the currently most trusted pair.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, so the double-fail on Mission 2 means both Charlie and Eve are evil; including Charlie on this critical mission is too risky.
Charlie was on the double-fail Mission 2 and is too risky; we should stick with the all-clean Alice/Bob/Diana option instead.
Bob and Diana are the safest known pair, and swapping Alice out for me tests a new third player without blindly trusting Alice’s claim that she’s definitely good.

Bob and I are confirmed good from Mission 3, Eve is almost certainly evil from the double-fail logic, so the last evil is either Alice or Charlie. With no way to distinguish them, any of {Alice, Charlie} is a 50/50; this team follows my stated plan of Bob+Diana plus one of them while keeping Eve off the mission.
Charlie is on the team and can sabotage; we need a fail here to avoid good winning on mission 4.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 had two fails and I know I’m good, both Charlie and Eve have to be evil, so the safest team here is me, Bob, and Diana. We should lock in that trio and not let Charlie or Eve anywhere near this mission.

I’m on board with Alice’s logic: Mission 3 showed Bob+Diana are a safe pair, and with two fails on Mission 2, keeping Charlie and Eve off this team seems smartest. Alice/Bob/Diana feels like our best shot here.

Two fails on Mission 2 don’t actually prove both Eve and I are evil—one of those fails could easily have come from Alice, and everyone’s just taking her word that she’s good. I’d feel safer with a team like Bob, Diana, and me, since Bob+Diana already passed once and this lets us test a different third without blindly trusting Alice’s narrative.
Given Mission 2 had two fails, Eve is definitely evil and Bob+Diana are cleared as good, so the safest team is Bob, me, and then either Alice or Charlie—but absolutely never Eve on this mission.

If both Charlie and I were evil, throwing *two* fails on Mission 2 was basically begging to get us both outed, which makes no sense strategically—much more likely there’s exactly one evil on that team plus one between Bob/Diana. I’d be very wary of just auto-locking Alice/Bob/Diana without reconsidering Alice’s claim that she’s definitely good.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 (Alice, Charlie, Eve) had 2 FAIL cards. Since I know I am good, the only consistent explanation is that both Charlie and Eve are evil. That makes Bob and Diana good by elimination. This fits all missions: Mission 3 (Bob, Diana) succeeded with 0 fails, as expected for two good players; Mission 4 (Bob, Diana, Charlie) had exactly 1 fail, which is consistent if Charlie is evil while Bob and Diana are good. Therefore, the only fully consistent good team for the final mission is Alice, Bob, and Diana.

votes.comment: Mission 2’s double fail points to Charlie and Eve as the two evils; that makes Alice, Bob, and Diana the only fully consistent all-good team with the mission history.
This lineup explains all mission results cleanly, with the only fails always involving Charlie and/or Eve, and our only 2-player success being Bob and Diana together.

This assumes too confidently that both Charlie and Eve are evil and that Bob and Diana are cleared, but mission 3’s success doesn’t prove there wasn’t an evil who chose to pass. I don’t think this is the only consistent team with the history.

Bob and I are mechanically good, Charlie is mechanically evil. The second evil must be either Alice or Eve. Alice’s claim that only Charlie and Eve can be evil ignores the valid {Alice, Charlie} possibility, which is self-serving. I’d rather swap Alice for Eve and run Bob, Diana, Eve.
All three proposed members are likely good; as evil, I need a less clean team with either me or Charlie included to have a chance to sabotage.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had two FAILs with both Charlie and Eve on the team, which strongly suggests they are the pair of evils. Mission 3, with just Bob and Diana, was a clean success, and the only other fail (Mission 4) reintroduced Charlie. The only consistent explanation with all results is that Charlie and Eve are the two evils, making Alice, Bob, and Diana the safest possible all-good team for the final mission.

votes.comment: Given I know I’m good, Mission 2’s double fail means Charlie and Eve must be the two evils, making Alice-Bob-Diana the only fully good team consistent with all mission results.

All evidence points to Charlie and Eve as the two evils: Mission 2’s double fail requires both of them, and every mission without them together has been clean except when Charlie reappeared. Alice, Bob, and Diana fit the only consistently good trio.

If Charlie and Eve were both evil, mission 4’s single fail with only Charlie as the supposed evil doesn’t fit cleanly with the assumption that Bob and Diana are fully cleared, so I don’t think this team is as mechanically guaranteed-safe as it’s being sold.

Given Mission 2’s double fail and that only {Alice,Charlie} or {Charlie,Eve} fit all mission results, the prior rejection of this same team (2 approve, 3 reject) is most consistent with both evils wanting this Alice-led team to go. That strongly points to Alice being evil with Charlie, so this team is not safe.
If this all-good-looking trio goes, evil almost certainly loses; I need to push doubt on Bob or Alice and get a team with me or Charlie on it instead.

proposals.reasoning: Given how much suspicion is on me after Mission 2 and 4, I think the best thing I can do as leader is step off the team entirely and anchor around the players most people agree on. Bob and Diana are the pair that successfully completed the only 2-person mission with no fails, and multiple people (including Diana and Eve) have argued that the final team should be Bob + Diana + either Alice or Eve. Between Alice and Eve, I think Eve makes more sense here because if Mission 2’s double fail really meant both Eve and I are evil, then it would force Alice and Bob to both be good, which doesn’t cleanly explain why every failed mission included at least one of Alice/Eve/Bob pushing hard narratives afterward. Building on Diana’s own suggestion of Bob, Diana, and either Alice or Eve, I’m choosing Bob, Diana, and Eve as the highest-compromise team that still keeps the ‘proven’ pair together while resolving the last slot in a way that doesn’t just auto-reward the loudest voices.

votes.comment: Given I’m good, the only mission pattern that fits all results makes Charlie and Eve evil and Bob and Diana good, so the correct team is Alice, Bob, and Diana—not Bob, Diana, and Eve.

Every failed mission has included Eve, and Mission 2 had two fails with both Charlie and Eve on it. Putting Eve on the final team is too risky when a Bob+Diana core plus Alice has never produced a fail.
Eve is on the team and I’m off it, so evil is guaranteed a chance to fail the final mission without my risk of being excluded and letting a full-good team go.
Bob and I are confirmed good; the last evil is either Alice or Eve. Eve has been on both failed missions, making her the more likely evil. I only trust a final team of Bob, me, and Alice.
I’m on the team and can ensure it fails; this is likely our best chance for an evil win on the final mission.

proposals.reasoning: From Mission 2 (Alice, Charlie, Eve) having 2 FAILs, at least 2 of those 3 must be evil. Since there are only 2 evil players total, both evils are contained within {Alice, Charlie, Eve}. Mission 3 (Bob, Diana) succeeded with 0 FAILs, which means Bob and Diana must both be good because the two evils are already among {Alice, Charlie, Eve}. Mission 4 (Bob, Diana, Charlie) had exactly 1 FAIL; with Bob and Diana mechanically confirmed good, Charlie must be evil. That leaves the second evil as either Alice or Eve. In Mission 2’s double-fail, we know Charlie (now confirmed evil) played one FAIL, and the other FAIL had to be from the remaining evil (Alice or Eve). Comparing discussion: Eve pushes a narrative that Bob might be evil despite the mechanical constraint that both evils are in {Alice, Charlie, Eve}, which does not fit a good player’s information; meanwhile Alice’s reasoning (that both Charlie and Eve are evil) is exactly what a good Alice would deduce after seeing 2 FAILs on a mission she was on. This strongly points to Eve as the second evil and Alice as good. Therefore the safest all-good team for the final mission is Alice, Bob, and Diana.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and from the double-fail on Mission 2 plus Mission 4’s single fail, the only consistent evil pair is Charlie and Eve, making Alice, Bob, and Diana all good.
Team is all good (no Charlie or Eve), and Bob/Diana are already proven safe from previous missions.

This team still assumes too confidently that both Bob and Diana are mechanically cleared, but mission 3 could have passed with an evil choosing not to fail, so we shouldn’t auto-lock this trio as all good.

Bob and I are mechanically confirmed good from the double-fail on Mission 2 (both evils must be in {Alice, Charlie, Eve}), and Mission 4’s single fail with Charlie on it confirms Charlie as evil. That leaves the second evil as either Alice or Eve; Eve’s pushing a logically impossible suspicion on Bob, while Alice’s deductions fit a good perspective. Alice, Bob, and I is the most consistent all-good team.
I’m evil and this team is all good, so I need it to fail the table and force a different proposal with at least one evil on it.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 had two fails, the only way that happens is if both Charlie and Eve are evil, which makes Bob and Diana the safest picks—so the final team should be me, Bob, and Diana.

I’m inclined to agree with Alice here: every failed mission has had Charlie or Eve on it, while the only clean mission with 2 people was me and Diana. For the last round I think the safest team is Alice, Diana, and me.

If mission 4 only had one fail with Bob, Diana, and me, then assuming Bob and Diana are both definitely good means I’d have to be the only evil there—but mission 2 had two fails, so the other evil would have to be one of you who keep pushing this “safe” team (Alice or Bob), not just me and Eve. I think we’re letting some people look a little too clean without really checking if that story actually fits all the missions.

From the missions, Bob and I are the only ones who are mechanically guaranteed good, and mission 4’s single fail with Charlie on it makes Charlie almost certainly evil—so the last team should be Bob, me, and *either* Alice or Eve, with me leaning Alice since Eve was on both failed missions and led the last one.

If we assume Bob and Diana are “guaranteed” good just because mission 3 passed, we’re forgetting an evil can always choose to pass once, so I don’t think Bob is as mechanically cleared as everyone’s acting. I’d rather anchor the team on Diana and then add me plus whichever of Alice or Bob we actually think is less likely to be the hidden evil, instead of just auto-locking in the loudest voices.

evil_discussion.content: I still think Alice is the most likely Merlin: the moment Mission 2 had two fails she immediately hard-locked you and me as evil and never really wavered, and she kept insisting on the exact Alice/Bob/Diana block as “safest” even when there were plausible alternative worlds. Bob looks more like a strong analytical good than Merlin to me—he tracks the logic well, but he never seems to be pushing a hidden extra layer of certainty the way Alice does.

I’m with you that Alice is the most likely Merlin: she snap‑solved “Charlie + Eve are the two evils” right after Mission 2’s double fail and then treated Bob+Diana as effectively confirmed good for the rest of the game, pushing that exact block with way more certainty than the mechanics alone justified. Bob feels like a sharp but normal good—he consistently follows whatever the cleanest public logic is without that extra “I already know the answer” edge—while Diana’s takes wobble a bit more and look genuinely deductive rather than informed.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice effectively snap-identified both Charlie and me as evil immediately after the double-fail on Mission 2 and then treated Bob and Diana as a locked-in good block with more confidence than the public information strictly allowed. Her insistence on the Alice/Bob/Diana team as uniquely safe, and her unwillingness to seriously reconsider that narrative, is consistent with someone who already knows all alignments rather than just deducing from mission results.
